THE

BHA·π¨·π¨I-K√ÇVYA

OR

R√ÇVA·πÜAVADHA

≈öRI BHA·π¨·π¨I

VOLUME I. CANTOS I.‚ÄîIX.

EDITED

WITH THE COMMENTARY OF MALLINATHA
AND
WITH CRITICAL AND EXPLANATORY NOTES
BY

KAMAL√Ç≈öA·πÑKARA PR√Ç·πÜASA·πÑKARA TRIVEDI, B. A.,

SANSKRIT, BHAVANAGARA COLLEGE AND ACTING PROFESSOR OF ORIENTAL

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ

‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç

( ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç)

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç

‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§Ç

‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§™‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ

‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•á ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•ß‡•Ø ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•Æ ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç

‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

CRITICAL NOTICE.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1725665452dasline.PNG"/>

In preparing the present edition of the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya the following MSS. have been used**:‚Äî**
C. A copy of the MS. in charge of the Asiatic Society of Bengal. It is the oldest of all the MSS. that I could collect, and though I tried my best to secure it for collation, I could not get it. I was, however, able to obtain a copy of it carefully written and compared by Mr. V√¢sudeva, a scribe of Calcutta. In his collec- tion of manuscripts Dr. R√¢jendral√¢la Mitra says as follows with regard to this MS. (Vide Vol. 6. Part. I. 1882, Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society):‚Äî

‚ÄúNo. 2082. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡§É‡•§ substance, country-made yellow paper, 14√ó3 inches, Folia 130. Lines on a page, 6. Extent, 2,900 S’lokas, Character, Bengali. Date, S’aka 1326. Place of Deposit, Calcutta, Government of India. Verse. Correct

Rava·πáa-Vadha. An epic poem in 22 Cantos . . . . . . The writing is in well-formed Bengali letters, differing in no respect from the Bengali writing by Pandits of the last century. The leaves are all stained by watermarks and the colour of the yellow orpiment with which they are dyed is very much faded, being unmistakable testimony to the age of the MS. The colour of the ink is well preserved, except in the marginal notes written at different times by different persons. The name of the scribe is Purushottam Deva S’arm√¢. The date of writing is S’aka 1326=A. D. 1403."
** Beginning:‚Äî‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç. ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡••**

‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É &c.

** End:‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç &c.**
Colophon**:‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§°‡§≠‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§ô‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•• ‡§∂‡§ï‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§É‡•ß‡•©‡•®‡•¨‡••**

B**.** This was obtained from Benares through my friend, Pa·πá·∏çita Govindad√¢sa, who secured it from his friend, Pa·πá·∏çita Parame≈õvara Datta Pandeya. It is in Devanagari characters and contains the text only. It has 8 lines on a page and is incorrect in many places. It has no date. It does not seem to be old.
** Beginning :‚Äî‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡•• ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É &c**

End :‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç &c.

** Colophon:‚Äî‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡••**

E1. This was secured from the Elphinstone College through Dr. Peterson. It contains the text only up to the fifth canto, in Devan√¢gar√Æ characters. The fourth and fifth cantos are designated as the fourth canto. It has a few marginal notes up to the third canto, copied for the most part from Jayamangal√¢. It is not a purely correct MS. It consists of 12 pages and is written in Samvat 1661. It has 12 or 13 lines on a page.

** Beginning:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É &c.**

** End:‚Äî‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•Å‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç &c**

** Colophon:‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡••**

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•ß‡•¨‡•¨‡•ß ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡•§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø ‡•ß‡•´‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

E2. This is the second MS. obtained from the Elphinstone College through Dr. Peterson. It contains the text only in Deva- n√¢gar√Æ characters and goes as far as the 10th Canto. It contains 8 lines on a page and is incorrect in many places. It is copied from a MS. in Bengali characters. There are notes on difficult words, mostly consisting of the meanings of roots, such as ‡§Ü‡§∏ ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§®‡•á. The marginal notes, particularly those in Canto X. on verses illustrating ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï and other Ala·πÖk√¢ras, are mostly copied from Jayamangala. The number of verses is not marked. It is dated the 14th Chaitra Vad, ≈öa·πÅvat 1790.

Beginning :‚Äî‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡••‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É &c.

End:‚Äî‡§∏‡•å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã &c.

Colophon:‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§π‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ß‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É‡••
‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§ï‡§É‡••

** ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•• ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡••**

‡§≠‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•≠‡•Ø‡•¶ ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§•‡•å ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å \‡•§\‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡••‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡••

E3. This is the third MS. received from the Elphinstone College through Dr. Peterson. It is complete and is accompanied by the commentary Jayama·πÖgal√¢. It is in Devan√¢gar√Æ characters and is dated Sa·πÅvat 1894.

** Beginning:‚Äî‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡•• ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É &c.**

** End:‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç &c.**

** Colophon:‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§**

** Colophon of the Commentary:‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ô‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§≤‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ü‡•Ä‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•• ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•• ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•Ø‡•™ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•ß‡•¶ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡••**

D. This was received from the Deccan College Library through Dr. Bh√¢·πá·∏ç√¢rakar. It is in Devan√¢gar√Æ characters and is very incorrect. In several places incomplete verses aregiven, the latter half being omitted. The copyist seems to be completely ignorant of the Sanskritlanguage. It contains

the complete text and the commentary of Jayama√±gal√¢. It is dated Sa·πÅvat 1869.
** Beginning :‚Äî‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§É&c.**

** End :‚Äî‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç &c.**

** Colophon :‚Äî‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§**

Colophon of the Commentary:‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ô‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á ‡§≤‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•ß‡•Æ‡•¨‡•Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø ‡•ß‡•ß ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§¶‡§§‡•ç

T‚ÇÅ. It is a copy of one of the MSS. of Bha·π≠·π≠i in the Tanjore Palace Sanskrit Library, which comprises a very extensive collection of MSS., having more than 10,000 Sanskrit Volumes. With all his efforts, my friend, Prof. S. R√¢dh√¢krish·πáa Aiyar, Principal, Mah√¢r√¢j√¢’s College, Pudukot√¢, could not get me the original MSS. I had, therefore, to be content with the copies of them, secured for me by him. It was only through his untiring efforts that I was able to get copies of these Southern MSS. To ensure the correctness of the copies he engaged Pa·πá·∏çita A. R. Thirumalachariar, of Mah√¢r√¢j√¢’s College, Pudukot√¢. It was through his exertions that the MSS. of the text in the Tanjore Palace Sanskrit Library were collated and that Sargas 10 to 22 of both the copies of the commentary of Mallin√¢tha (the one in the Theosophical Society’s Library, Adyar, Madras, and the other from Coimbatore) were copied, as also the commentary of Mallin√¢tha (Granth, printed) of the first 9 Sargas :

This MS. is written in Devan√¢gar√Æ characters and contains 68 pages. It is noted as a recent copy in Dr. Burnell’s cata- logues, but it seems a little old. It is corrected and hence correct. It invariably contains 14 lines on each page. Additions, correc- tions, and differences of reading are marked on the margins

(right, left, top and bottom). Portions to be omitted are not erased with ink, but covered with a coloured paste. Sheets are loose, neither bound nor stitched. There are no remarks on the opening page. The copyist’s name, place, and year are not known. The writing is beautiful. The MS. is complete. The headings and the concluding portion are written in red ink.

T

2

. This is a copy of another Tanjore MS. It is written in Grantha characters and contains 80 cadgan leaves. It is incomplete, and comes up to the 10th verse of the 16th Canto. Verses from 31 to 45 of the 15th Canto are omitted and those from 46 to 113 given irregularly. The MS. appears to be old, being eaten in several places by worms. It has 6 or 7 lines on each page. The copyist’s name, place, and year are not known.

T

3

. This is a copy of the third Tanjore MS. It contains 59 cadgan leaves of the text in Grantha characters and 235 leaves of the commentary of Jayamangal√¢ in Devan√¢gar√Æ characters. Though worm-eaten in some places, it is legible. It has 7, 8 or 9 lines on each page. It appears very old. The verses are not numbered. The last verse (35,‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç&c., of the 22nd Canto) is not found in the MS. It ends as follows**:‚Äî**

** ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡••**

‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∞‡§µ‡•å ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡•§
‡§µ‡•á‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ü‡•á‡§∂‡•á‡§® ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§§‡•á‡••

T

4

This is a copy of the fourth Tanjore MS. It is writeenin Grantha characters and contains 120 leaves. The last leaf (120) is lost and the MS. ends with the word ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É in the verse 31 of the 22nd Canto,

I got two other MSS. after the text had been printed off for the most part. The readings of these are therefore given in the Appendix. Of these the first designated Ds is in the Deccan College Government Collection. I collated it in the College while I was acting as Professor of Oriental Languages there. It is incomplete, proceeding up to St. 26, C. XII. It bears no date.

The second was secured by me through my friend, Mr. Amidhara Ra·πáacchodaj√Æ Des√¢i, Assistant Master, Ahmed√¢b√¢d High School, from Pa·π≠·π≠a·πáa. His brother, Mr. Haridhara R. Des√¢i, B. A., was kind enough to collate it for me, and also send the MS. to me. I then collated it myself. The MS. bears no date and proceeds up to the 10th Canto. It is incorrect in many places. It is designated P. in the Appendix.

For the commentary of Mallin√¢tha I have consulted four Southern copies. The first is a printed copy in Grantha characters from Canto I. to Canto IX. The second is also a printed copy in Telugu characters from Canto I. to Canto IX. The third is a copy of the MS. of Bha·π≠·π≠i with the commentary of Mallin√¢tha in charge of the Theosophical Society of Madras from Canto X. to the end. The phrase ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•É‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§Éabounds in the MS. without exception in the beginning and end of every Sarga. The commentary is so full of mistakes that it would require as much time to be corrected as itself to be copied. The blank spaces are to be filled up with very great care and attention. The fourth and the best copy of the commentary was secured from R√¢ma S√¢striar of Kadathur, near Udamalpet, Coimbatore District. It is about 80 or 100 years old. It contains 158 pages with 12 or 13 lines on a page and is written in Grantha characters. 15 leaves are worm-eaten. Telugu notes appear in one or two places as in describing the metre of the 19th Canto. The MS. is very correct. There are no orthographical blunders in the first three-fourths of the book. In the last few pages which are also remarkably correct, there are a few mistakes such as the indiscriminate use of da and dha for da and dha. I got a copy of this excellent MS. of the commentary through the indefatiguable energy of Prof. S. R√¢dh√¢- krish·πáa Aiyar, who writes to me as follows:‚ÄîYou will be glad to hear that I have after all succeeded in my attempt to secure another copy of Mallin√¢tha’s commentary on the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya. It was obtained from R√¢ma S√¢striar of Kadathur with some difficulty no doubt. I doubt whether the copy would ever have

reached me, were it not for the kindness and the official position of my friend, Mr. Sriniv√¢sa Aiyar, B. A., Stationary Sub-Magistrate of the place in Coimbatore.

I must consider you fortunate, as the Pandit tells me that the writing is very legible (Grantha) and that the commentary is complete with the exception of that of a portion (10 S’lok√¢s) in the 10th Chapter for which blank space is provided in the palmleaf Manuscript. The MS. appears to be about 100 years old and is pronounced to be correct."

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

INTRODUCTION.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-17257206511.PNG"/>

The Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya, otherwise known as R√¢va·πáavadha, is a grammatical poem, composed by the poet Bha·π≠·π≠i with the object of illustrating Pa·πáin√Æ’s S√ªtras. It is, as Mallin√¢tha calls it, an Ud√¢hara·πáa-K√¢vya or illustration-poem of the Sutras of P√¢·πáini. It is divided into four sections, Prak√Ær·πáa-K√¢·πá·∏ça, Adhikara-K√¢·πá·∏ça Prasanna-K√¢·πá·∏ça, and Ti√±anta-K√¢·πá·∏ça, The first of these sections, comprising the first five Cantos, illustrates miscellaneous Sutras at random. The second section embraces four Cantos from the fifth to the ninth, and illustrates what are known as *Adhik√¢ra- S√∫tras1*or head-rules that exercise a kind of governing influence on certain subsequent rules, having to be repeated in them all. Taddhita and K·πõit affixes, changes of ‡§®‡•ç to ‡§£‡•çand ‡§∏‡•ç to, ‡§∑‡•ç addition of ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç to certain roots in Perfect, rules of Gu·πáa and V·πõiddhi in ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç Aorist, government of cases and similar portions of grammar come under this section, in which verses are so arranged that they illustrate the Sutras of Panini in the order of the Ash·π≠√¢dhy√¢y√Æ, excepting only those that are applicable to the Vedic literature. Illustrations of miscellaneous Sutras are interspersed here and there between those of Adhik√°ra-S√ªtras. The third section illustrates a portion of poetics, touching figures of speech (both S’abdalank√¢ras and Arth√¢lank√¢ras), Gu·πáas Madhurya and Bhavika, and Bh√¢sh√°sama, a figure of speech in which wordsare so selected and arranged that the sentence belongs at once to Sa·πÅsk·πõita and Pr√¢k·πõita. This section takes up four Cantos from the 10th to the 13th. The remaining nine Cantos illustrate all the Tenses and Moods, all the Lak√°ras except ‡§≤‡§ü‡•çwhich is concerned only with the Vedic literature.

The Bha·π≠·π≠i**-**K√¢vya is a work of great renown. It is held to be a sort of authority on questions of grammar. When a particular form occurring in it seems to violate P√¢·πáini, it is with great reluctance that commentators call it Pram√¢da or a mistake. Great ingenuity is shewn in establishing its correctness. Bha·π≠·π≠oji D√Ækshita has quoted instances from the work2, ’ ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ’ ‡•ß, ‡•ß‡•¨ (‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ p. 45, 46 ), ’ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ’ ‡•ß, ‡•®‡•© ( K. p. 279), ’ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ’ ‡•®, ‡•ß‡•¶ ( ‡§Æ‡•¶‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ p. 73) ’ ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç ’ ‡•®, ‡•™‡•® ( ‡§Æ‡•¶‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ p. 51 ), ‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ’ ‡•©, ‡•ß‡•Æ ( K. p. 227 ), ‘‡§® ‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§≤‡•á‡§≠‡•á ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ’ ‡•©, ‡•®‡•≠ (‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ p. 14), ‘‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡•Å‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§™‡•Å‡§É ’ ‡•™, ‡•´, ( ‡§Æ‡•¶‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ p.65), ’ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü ‡§®‡•à‡§ï‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ? ‡•™, ‡•ß‡•® ( ‡§Æ‡•¶‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ p. 104), ’ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§’ ‡•™, ‡•®‡•Æ ( K. p. 234 ), ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡§æ ‡§π‡§§‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ ’ ‡•´ ‡•Æ ( K. p. 88 ), ’ ‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å’ ‡•´, ‡•ß‡•ß ( K. p. 28 and ‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ p. 29), ’ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ’ ‡•¨, ‡•´‡•™ ( K. p. 291), ‘‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§™‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ’ ‡•≠, ‡•®‡•Æ (‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ p. 68 ), ‡•§ ! ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç ’ ‡•≠, ‡•ß‡•¶‡•© Com. (K. p. 275 ), ’ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•ß‡•¶, ‡•® 275), ’ ( ‡§Æ‡•¶‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ p. 61), ’ ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡•ß‡•´, ‡•®‡•ß (‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ p. 45 ), and ’ ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§ò‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•å ‡•ß‡•Æ, ‡•ß‡•Ø ( K. p. 34 ).")in his Siddh√¢nta-Kaumud√Æ and Manoram√¢, in some cases to support his view of the S√ªtras and in others to explain their apparent deviation from them.3The fact that he has to explain their departures from P√¢·πáini, saying **‚Äò‡§ï‡§•‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§É‚Äô**establishes the authoritativeness of the work. Another work that like the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya is known to illustrate the rules of P√¢·πáini’s grammar, is the R√¢va·πá√¢rjun√Æya, composed by Bhaumaka4and well-known in K√¢s’mira. Bhaumaka lived

before Jay√¢ditya, the author of the K√¢s’ik√¢, and the K√¢s’mira poet Kshemendra; because the K√¢s’ik√¢ contains a quotation from the R√¢va·πá√¢rjun√Æya. The following half verse is quoted in the V·πõitti on the S√ªtra ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù ‡•®‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•©‡••from Bhaumaka’s poem:‚Äî

‚Äò‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§†‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§†‡§ï‡•å‡§•‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§‚Äô

The same verse is quoted in the Siddh√¢nta-Kaumud√Æ also. The whole verse is**:‚Äî**

‚Äò‡§â‡§¶‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§†‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§†‡§ï‡•å‡§•‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‚Äô ‡•≠.‡•™.‡••

i.e ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§∏‡§≠‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§π ‡§¶‡§∂‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂. Kshemendra’s Suv·πõittatilaka has a verse **‘‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡•å‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á‡••‚Äô ‡•©, ‡•™.**naming Bha·π≠·π≠i and Bhanmaka. This work is more artificial5 being generally illustrated by one Canto ( ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É, ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É, ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§°‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É and so forth ).")than the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya and this perhaps is the reason why it has not become so popular.

The subject treated in the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya is the story of R√¢ma, whose virtues and exploits have given scope to so many poets to shew their powers.6 Beginning with DasÃÅaratha, the
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

and this is confirmed by the Extracts in B√ºhler’s own Report. See Appendix to that work LXXXV. I. 19 ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡§¢‡•ç‡§¢‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø which should be corrected to ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø, and not as is done in the note, and I. 23 ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•áa reading which should not be marked as a doubtful reading. Bh√ªma, or Bh√ªmaka and Bhaumaka are variations easily explained by the Kashmir pronunciation.” (Dr. Peterson’s Preface to Subhashitavali p. 83). A. Deccan College Manuscript (No. 184 collection of 1875-76) ascribes the work to the poet Bhima. ‚Äò‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‚Äô and so forth at the end of each Canto. But Kshemendra in his Suv·πõittatilaka gives Bhaumaka as the name of the author.

work comes down to the destruction of R√¢vana and Rama’s return to Ayodhy√¢. It is a Mah√¢-k√¢vya,7as the oldest.commentator Jayama·πÖgala, Mallin√¢tha, and others call it.8 Being composed with the special object of illustrating the rules of

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

N·πõisi·πÅha Pur√¢·πáa, Padma-Pur√¢·πáa, and other Pur√¢·πáas, in Yoga- va≈õish·π≠ha, Kalid√¢sa’s Raghuva≈õs’a, Kaviraja’s R√¢ghava P√¢·πádav√Æya, Bhavabh√ªti’s Uttarar√¢macharita, and V√Æracharita, R√¢jasekhara’s B√¢lar√¢m√¢ya·πáa, Jayadeva’s Prasannaraghava and many other works. Jayadeva hits the mark when he says**:‚Äî**

‚Äò‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É‡•§
‡§Ø‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•à‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ó‚Äì
‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡§É‡••‚Äô

grammar, it can not be expected to come up in point of beauty to any one of the well-known Mah√¢-K√¢vyas. Still it must be said in fairness to the author that the work is by no means dry or dull, and that there are many passages9, 25, 41, 47. Canto III., Sts. 12-14, 51-55; Canto IV., Sts. 35, 36, 38, 39. Canto V., Sts. 10-45, 51, 71-74,84-89, 102. Canto, VI., 10-39, R√¢ma’s grief for Sita (73-85), 104, 105. Canto VII., the description of the rainy season and R√¢ma’s state in it ( 1-13), 96-99, 106-109. Canto VIII., 82-84, 95-98, 104‚Äì126. Canto IX. 55-57, 107, 110-136.")in it, which can stand comparison with the best passages of any of the Mah√¢-K√¢vyas.

Having thus informed the reader of the nature of the work, its contents, and popularity, I now turn to the question of the name of the author and the age in which he lived. Colebrooke considers Bhart·πõihari to be the author of the work. He says**:‚Äî**The opening Stanza of the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya may serve as an instance of Ruchird metre. The poem, bearing that title, is on the subject of the adventures of R√¢ma. It is composed in twenty-two Cantos. Being composed purposely for the practical illustration of grammar, it exhibits a studied variety of diction, in which words anomalously inflected are most frequent. The style, however, is neither obscure nor inelegant, and the poem reckoned among the classical compositions in the Sanskrit language. The author was Bhart·πõihari, not as might be supposed, the celebrated brother of Vikram√¢ditya, but a grammarian and poet who was son of S’r√Ædharasw√¢min as we are informed by one of his scholiasts, Vidy√¢vinoda.’10

Dr. Bhau D√¢ji remarks that Bha·π≠·π≠i is popularly believed to have been a son of Bhartrihari.11 S’√¢str√ÆS’eshagiri observes:‚Äî

‚ÄúThe name Vikram√¢ditya is applied to several kings and consequently causes considerable confusion. The first sovereign that is known by it was the Vikram√¢ditya from whom the well-known era takes its name. He is said to have been the son of a Brahma·πáa, named Chandragupta, who married four wives, one of the Brahman caste, another of the Kshatriya, the third of the Vais’ya, and the fourth of the S’udra caste. They were called Brahmani, Bh√¢numati, Bh√¢gyavat√Æ, and Sindhumat√Ærespectively. Each of the four bore him a son. Vararuchi was born of the first wife, Vikram√¢rka of the second, Bha·π≠·π≠i of the third, and Bhartrihari of the fourth. Vikramarka became king while Bha·π≠·π≠i served him as Prime-Minister. After an incredibly long reign he is said to have been killed by a Prince of the potter caste, named S’aliv√¢hana in 56 B. C. and in that year commences his era”.12In his Preface to the S’atakas Bohlen remarks**:‚Äî‚ÄúThey say that Vikrama in fact got possession of the kingdom and took to himself Bhatti as Prime-Minister. But in this again they seem to have gone wrong, confounding both persons and times. For there exists a grammatical poem called Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya, describing at the same time the exploits of R√¢ma, which has been attributed to a certain grammarian belonging to a later age called Bhartrihari, and from the name of this poem, I think, Bha·π≠·π≠i seems to have been considered as the brother of this, our Bhart·πõihari."13 These writers seem to have been misled by what some of the Commentators on the work have said. N√¢r√¢ya·πáavidy√¢vinod√¢ch√¢rya14gives Bhart·πõihari as the name of the author. He thus begins his commentary, which he calls Bha·π≠·π≠ibodhin√Æ:‚Äî‚Äú‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§¶ ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ-**

‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§‚Äù.Vidy√¢vinoda also calls his commentary Bha·π≠·π≠i-chandrik√¢ and the author Bhart·πõihari, son of Sr√Ædharasv√¢min:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§É‡•§’.Kandarpachakravartin does the same:‚Äì‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§. ‘Bharata-mallika, ‘who lived at K√¢nch√¢rp√¢r√¢ in the Hooghly district, about 150 years ago,’15 speaks of Bhart·πõihari as the author of the work in his commentary, Mugdhabodhin√Æ:‚Äî‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ú‡§É‡•§ ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•ã **‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• …… ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•§’.**The manuscript from Benares, collated by me, and designated B., calls the poem Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya at the end of each Canto without naming the author,16but at the end of the twelfth Canto it states ‚Äò‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§‚Äô

** **This is all the evidence that could be gathered in favour of calling the author Bhart·πõihari or of connecting Bha·π≠·π≠i with Bhart·πõihari. Let us now examine it minutely and see whether it is reliable. Colebrooke has no independent evidence to stand upon, his statement being, as he himself tells us, simply based upon that of Vidy√°vinoda. Bohlen too rests his conclusion on mere tradition and on the statement of some of the commentators. Though the commentators N√¢r√°ya·πáa Vidyavinod√¢ch√¢ry√¢, Vidy√¢vinoda, Kandarpachakravartin and Bharata call the author Bhart·πõihari, still they name the work Bha·π≠·π≠i without however assigning any reason why it should have been so styled.

We thus come to two questions, I, whether Bha·π≠·π≠i is the name of the author of the poem known as Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya, and II.

whether he was identical with Bhartrihari or distinct from him. The oldest manuscript C. and two other manuscripts D‚ÇÇand T‚ÇÉdistinctly call the work R√¢va·πáavadha and the author Bha·π≠·π≠i. Jayamangala and Mallin√¢tha, both call the author Bha·π≠·π≠i. Traditions described by Dr. Bhau D√¢ji and S’√¢stri S’eshagiri mention Bhatti and Bhartrihari as two distinct persons. In the Index to Professor Aufrecht’s catalogue of the Oxford MSS. Bha·π≠·π≠i is stated to be the author of the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya.17 Bhatti’s name is found in a verse in the Bhojaprabandha18.Bha·π≠·π≠i is mentioned by name by Kshemendra19 of the 11th century and Vallabhadeva of the 15th century. In Vallabhadeva’s Subhashitavali, both Bha·π≠·π≠i and Bhartrihari have been separately cited. In the last-named work verses are quoted from the Bha·π≠·π≠i-k√¢vya under three names, Bha·π≠·π≠i, Bhattasvamin, and Bhartrisvamin.20 C. II. St. 19 ‡§® ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§® ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•å ‡§® ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ó‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É‡••‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§É- (No. 1819 in Dr. Peterson’s Subh√¢. ) C. II. St. 6. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§’ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡§π‡§§‡•á‡§Ω‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§É No. 2164 in Dr. Peterson’s Subha. ) C. II.St5, ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•à‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡••‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§É(No. 1811 in Dr.Peterson’s Subb√¢. ) C. XI. St. 21.‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡•ã‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§≤‡§ï‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡••‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§É (No. 2139 in Dr. Peterson’s Subha.)")Two

verses, which are assigned to Bha·π≠·π≠

i in the Subhashitavali, are attributed to Bha·π≠·π≠

asvamin and Bhart·πõisv√¢min in the S’√¢rnga- dharapaddhati of the fourteenth century.21 attributed to Bhatti in the Subh√¢shit√¢vali is mentioned under the name of Bhattasv√¢min in the S’√¢rngadharapaddhati. The reading there is ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§∑‡§É in place of ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ã‡§™. ( Vide No. 591 in Dr. Peterson’s edition of S’√¢riga.).‡§® ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§ú‡§Ç &c. ( C. II. St. 19 ) is in the S’√¢rngadharapaddhati attributed to Bhart·πõisv√¢min (Vide No. 3904 in Dr. Peterson’s edition of S’ariga.).")The Jayamangal√† as given in the Deccan College manuscript, designated D. by me, calls the work Bhart·πõi-Kavya and the author Bhart·πõi.22 ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§")At the end of each Canto in the manuscript the word Bhart·πõi- k√¢vya and not Bha·π≠·π≠

i-k√¢vya is found. I am therefore of opinion that Bha·π≠·π≠

i, Bha·π≠·π≠

asv√¢min, and Bhart·πõisv√¢min are three names of the same person. In his big Catalogue of Manuscripts Aufrecht says**:‚Äî**Bha·π≠·π≠

i called also Bhart·πõi- sv√¢min or Bha·π≠·π≠

asv√¢min or Sv√¢mibha·π≠·π≠

a, author of the Bha·π≠·π≠

i-K√¢vya’. That he was son of S’r√Ædharasv√¢min or S’r√Æ- sv√¢min is mentioned by many commentators23. Bhart·πõi must have been his name, as is found in the Jayama·πÖgal√¢ of the

MS. D. Bha·π≠·π≠

i is the Pr√¢k·πõita form of the Sa·πÅsk·πõita, word Bhart·πõi and his father’s name being S’r√Æsv√¢min or S’r√Ædhara-sv√¢min, he was called Bhart·πõisv√¢min, a combination of the name Bhart·πõi with the family appendage, Sv√¢min. The Gujar√¢ti names contain many instances of this kind. If the father’s name ends in S’ankara, R√¢ma, N√¢r√¢ya·πáa, or some such word, the son’s name also generally ends in the same form. Bha·π≠·π≠

a must have been his surname, and it being combined with Sv√¢min, he was called Bha·π≠·π≠asvamin or Sv√¢mibha·π≠·π≠a.24; but for this there seems to be no authority.")Thus Bha·π≠·π≠i being the Pr√¢krita form and probably the pet-name, became the most commonly known and the author came to be popularly called by it. Finally as Bha·π≠·π≠i does not look like a proper name, and is the Pr√¢k·πõita form of Bhart·πõi, later scholiasts25 were misled in calling him Bhart·πõihari, parti- cularly as the latter was well known as a grammarian.

Let me now turn to the question of the age of the author. He composed his work, as he himself informs us, in Valabh√é (modern Val√¢, the chief town of the native state of the same name in the Gohilw√¢·∏ça Pr√¢nta in K√¢·π≠hiaw√¢·∏ça) in the time of Dharasena. The last verse of this Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya runs as follows**:‚Äî**

‚Äò‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‚Äô

In the word S’r√Æ-Dharasena used in the above verse, S’r√é is simply honorific.26The copperplate grants of Valabh√Æ kings that have come to hand shew that there were four kings of the name of Dharasena.27 The dates of Dharasena I. can not be
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1726328014pic.PNG"/>

ascertained, as none of his grants have been hitherto discovered. The extreme limits between Dharasena II. and Dharasena IV. seem to be 80 years, as the earliest grant, hitherto known, of Dharasena II. is dated Sa·πÅvat 252, and the latest grant of Dharasena IV. is dated Sa·πÅvat 332. A grant of Dhruvasena III. is dated Sa·πÅvat 332. This settles the date of the end of Dharasena IV.’s reign. The beginning of his reign is less certain, as only one grant of his predecessor, Dhruvasena II., dated Sa·πÅvat 310, has been found. The Sa·πÅvat referred to in these grants is the Valabhi or Gupta era,28the first year of which corresponds to A. D. 319 as settled by a stone inscription of Soman√¢th-Pattana, shewing a grant of Arjunadeva of Gujarat.29. The original of it is in the temple of Harsata at Ver√¢val.")The inscription is dated in the Hijra year 662, Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 1320, Valabh√Æ Sa·πÅvat 945, and Simha Sa·πÅvat 151, Ash√¢·∏çha Vadi 13.30 Ranka, a disaffected subject of Valabh√Æ, bribed the Arab lord of Mans√ªra to send a naval expedition against Valabhi. ‘In a night attack king Valabha was killed and his people and town were destroyed’. Bombay Gazetteer Vol. I. Part I. p. 94.") Thus Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 376 or S’aka 242 was the first year of the Valabhi era. As Al-bir√ªn√Æ states, S’aka S. 242 and Vikrama Sa·πÅvat 376 was the starting-point of the Gupta or Valabhi era (’era of Balab’). Gukasena’s son Dharasena II. is considered to be the patron of Bha·π≠·π≠i by Lassen, but this is nothing more than a mere guess.31 The name of Bha·π≠·π≠i is found

in two Valabh√é copperplates. In Dhruvasena I.’s grant, dated Sa·πÅvat 221, he is described as an officer superintending the king’s kitchen and as executive officer.‚Äò‡§¶‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§§‡§ø’.32His name is also found as that of the done in Dhruvasena III.’s grant, dated Sa·πÅvat 334.‘‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‚Äî‚Äò‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ (‡§ï) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡•à‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§≠‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø33 ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•á ‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§É . . . . . . . . . .‡§â‡§¶‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É‡•§ ‘If the34 Bha·π≠·π≠i of these two grants be the same as our poet, it gives him a rather long life.35There is, however, no evidence to prove that the poet Bha·π≠·π≠i is identical with the Bha·π≠·π≠i of these grants, nor is there any evidence to prove which of the Dharasenas was his patron. From the fact that the Valabhi dynasty was at no time free from vassalage except in the reign of Dhara- sena IV., who calls himself ’ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§É‚Äô some think that the Dharasena referred to by Bha·π≠·π≠i in his last, verse is Dharasena IV. The well-known Sanskrit poem Bha·π≠·π≠i- K√¢vya seems to have been composed in the reign of this king as at the end of his work the author says it was written at Valabhi protected (governed) by the king, the illustrious Dharasena.

The author’s application to Dharasena of the title Narendra, Lord of Men, is a further proof of his great power’ (Bombay Gazetteer Vol. I. Part I. p. 92). But even Dharasena I. calls himself Mah√¢s√¢manta as well as Mah√¢r√¢ja and therefore the application of the word ‡§®‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞hardly warrants the conclusion that the supreme lord, the Chakravartin Dharasena, i. e. Dharasena IV., is alluded to by the poet. Thus it is difficult to decide in the present state of our knowledge what particular Dharasena was the author’s patron. But this much is certain that one of them was and that therefore our poet lived in the latter part of the sixth and the beginning of the seventh century.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

COMMENTARY.

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-172607140411.PNG"/>

The following are the commentaries on the Bhatti- K√¢vya**:‚Äî**

Jayamangala by Jayamangala.
One by Harihara.
Kalapadipika by Pun·∏çarik√°ksha, son of Srikanta.
Vaijayanti by Kandarpas’arman or Kandarpachakra- vartin.
Bha·π≠·π≠ichandrika by Vidy√¢vinoda.
Mugdhabodha by R√¢m√¢nanda.
Mugdhabodhini by Bharatamallika.
Subodhini by Kumud√¢nanda.
Bhattibodhini by Naraya·πáavidyavinoda.
Subodhini by R√¢machandrav√¢chaspati.
Kalapadipika by Vidy√¢sagara.
Bh√¢sh√°v·πõitti by Purushottama.
Sarvapathina by Mallin√¢tha.

Of these Jayama·πÖgal√¢ by Jayama·πÖgala is the oldest and has become the most popular. It explains all the grammatical forms well. Some of the above commentaries name other authorities than P√¢·πáini. Bh√¢shav·πõitti makes K√¢tantra36its grammatical authority. Bha·π≠·π≠ibodhini explains all grammatical references by citing the authority of the Sa·πÖkshiptas√¢ra grammar.37 Kal√¢pad√épik√¢ explains the text by references to the

rules of the Ka√¢pa**-**Vy√¢kara·πáa. Bharatamallika quotes the S√ªtras from the Mugdhabodha38grammar in explaining the forms.

Mallin√¢tha’s commentary on the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya like his famous commentary on the well-known Mah√¢k√¢vyas is a running commentary, explaining each word in the order of the Anvaya (grammatical sequence), marking points of grammar and Alank√¢ra and citing authorities. He is true to his promise**‚Äî’** ‡§á‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§®‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á !!’. It is an excellen: commentary. It is not so well-known as Jayama·πÖgal√¢ firstly because Jayamangal√¢ is a very old commentary39and secondly because Jayamangal√¢ explains each and every grammatical form very minutely, and analyses it fully. Mallin√¢tha in this commentary as in others notes not only the points of grammar, but also of Alankara, cites Koshas in support of his meanings, and names and explains metres. As regards knotty points of the philosophy of grammar, apart from those that concern the derivation of forms only Mallin√¢tha goes very deep. He has. criticized Jayamangal√¢ in many places40 C. IV. 21 (without naming him)."). In one place he has criticized Subodhinik√¢ra also.41The fifteenth century is the date

fixed for Mallin√¢tha.42In this commentary, however, there are two allusions to the Kaumudi (the Siddh√¢nta-Kaumudi of Bha·π≠·π≠oji Dikshita),43 and as the time of Bha·π≠·π≠oji Dikshita is fixed to be the 17th century,44 ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É (‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ) ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§É ( ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ) Vide. Introduction to the Rasagang√¢dhara (N. S. Press). Jagannatha lived in the reign of Shah Jahan and thus the beginning of the 17th century is the time of Bhattoji-Dikshita.") the question arises whether this Mallinatha is identical with the well-known Mallin√¢tha, the commentator on the famous Mahakavyas. In fact we have to decide three questions. I. Whether Mallinatha, the commenta- tor on the Bhatti-Kavya, is the same as the well-known Malli- natha. II. Whether Mallin√¢tha lived before Bha·π≠·π≠oji Dikshita or after him. III. Whether the references represent the com- mentator’s actual words or whether they are later interpolations. As regards the first question**:‚Äî**

On comparing this commentary with those of Mallinatha on the Raghuva·πÅsa, the Kum√¢ra-Sambhava the Meghad√ªta, the S’is’up√¢lavadha and the Kir√¢t√¢rjun√Æya, I am convinced that the two persons are identical. I find the same references to the K√¢s’ik√¢, V√¢mana and Ny√¢sakara, the same definitions of figures of speech mostly drawn from Vidy√¢n√¢tha’s Prat√¢parudra, the same allusions to Dandin, and quotations from the same Koshas, Amara, Y√†dava, Vis’va, Bha·π≠·π≠amalla. Moreover the commentator on the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya himself shews his identity with the well-known Mallin√¢tha by alluding to his commentary GhantƒÅpatha twice ( ‘‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ò‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‚Äì

‡§™‡§•‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á’ C. I., St. 6, and ‘‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§¶ ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§™‡§•‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§≠‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ’ C. XIV, St. 54), Sanj√évini on the Raghuvam≈õa (‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‘ C. I., St. 25), and Sanj√Ævin√Æ on the Kum√¢rasambhava ("‡§ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ô‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ä‡§ô‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•å ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‚Äù by ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ he means ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, and the reference is found there C. V. St. 43). We also find the same name ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø. The word ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø is derived in the same way in the Bha·π≠·π≠i - K√¢vya 2. 26 and the Kir√¢tarjun√éya 1. 21. All the above circumstances leave no ground to doubt his identity with the well-known Mallin√¢tha, unless we were to hazard a conjecture, a conjecture which has not the slightest argument to stand upon, that the commentator on the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya not only assumed the name and the surname of Mallinatha, imitating him so very cleverly and exactly in every respect as to pass for him, but he was also so very dishonest that he proved his own identity by speaking of Mallin√¢tha’s commentary on the Kir√¢t√¢rjun√Æya, the Raghuvams’a and the Kumarasambhava as his own. It is thus proved that the two Mallin√¢thas are not two distinct persons, but one and the same.

With regard to the second question whether Mallin√¢tha flourished before Bha·π≠·π≠oji D√ékshita or after him, it has already been mentioned before that Mallin√¢tha is assigned to the fifteenth century and Bha·π≠·π≠oji Dikshita to the 17th century. If Mallin√¢tha flourished after Bha·π≠·π≠oji D√Ækshita, we should find some allusion to the Siddh√¢ntakaumud√Æ in any one of the many passages45, ’ ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á’ ‡•ß, ‡•Ø ( K. p. 117), ’ ‡§∏ ‡§¨‡§≠‡•Ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ’ ‡•ß,‡•ß‡•¨ (K, p. 303), ‘‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø’ ‡•ß, ‡•´‡•™ ( K. p. 214 ) ‚Ä¢ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•å ’ ‡•®, ‡•©‡•© ( K. p. 259), ’ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡•®, ‡•© ‡•¨ (Ma. Pt. p. 66 ), ‘‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡•à‡§∞‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•á ’ ‡•©, ‡•ß‡•® (Ma. Utta. p. 99 ), ’ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§É ‡•©, ‡•™‡•´ ( Ma Pa p. 63), ‘‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§®‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ’ ‡•©, ‡•™‡•´, ( K. p. 291), ‘‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ’ ‡•™, ‡•®‡•¶ ( K. p. 83), ’ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∞‡§ò‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ò‡§æ‡§É ’ ‡•™, ‡•™‡•Ø (K. p. 117 ), ’ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§∞‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•à‡§É ’ ‡•´, ‡•¨‡•Ø (K. p. 234 ).")qnoted from the Raghuva·πÅs’a, the Kum√¢ra

sambhava, the Meghad√ªta, The K√ér√¢tarjun√éya, the ≈öi≈õup√¢lavadha in the Kaumud√Æ and the Manoram√¢**.** Moreover though there are so many passages quoted from the Bha·π≠·π≠i-K√¢vya in the Kaumud√Æ and the Manoram√° ( vide foot-note p. x. ), no references ( are given in the commentary except in two places C. I. St. 23, and C. VIII. St. 16. As Mallin√¢tha frequently quotes from the Kasi’k√¢ and follows it as in explaining the forms ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡•ß. ‡•ß‡•¶ (taking ‡§á‡§®‡§ø and not ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ) and ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§ ‡•ß. ‡•ß‡•¨ ( taking ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ to mean ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£ as in the V·πõitti and not ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ as in the Siddh√¢nta-Kaumud√Æ ), and as some of his readings, such as ‚Äò‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§Ç ‘‡§ö‡•Å‡§≤‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç,‚Äô & VƒÅrtika on ‚Äú‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ü‡§ø‚Äù ‡•©\‡•§‡•ß\‡•§‡•©‡•´\‡•§\‡•§ and ‚Äò‡§°‡§ö‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç’ a V√¢rtika on ‚Äú‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡•å ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ø‡•á ‡§°‡§ú‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‚Äù ‡•´‡•§‡•™‡•§‡•©‡•• are found to agree with those of the K√¢s’ik√¢ and not of the Kaumud√Æ, and as notwithstanding so many quotations from the well-known five Mah√¢k√¢vyas and from the Bha·π≠·π≠i-Kavya, Mallin√¢tha does not refer to the Kau,
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡•¶ ’ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•®, ‡•´‡•´ ( K. p. 56 ),‚Äò‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡§æ ‡•´, ‡•©‡•™ (Ma. P√ª. p. 57 ), ’ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø’ ‡•≠, ‡•Ø‡•© (K. p. 213).

‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡•¶. ‚Äò‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§É ‡§ï‡•å‡§§‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•ã‡§É‚Äô ‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ ‡•© (Ma. P√ª. p. 66 ).

‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡•¶. ‚Äò‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§µ‡•å‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äô ‡•ß, ‡•© (Ma. P√ª. 73 ),‚Äò**‡§® ‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‚Äô**‡•ß, ‡•™ (K. p. 803), ‘‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§É ‡•ß, ‡•´ ( K. p. 276), ‚Äò‡§∏ **‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äô**‡•ß, ‡•ß‡•¶ (Ma. Utta, p. 64 ) ‚Äò‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡§æ‡§ü‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‚Äô ‡•®, ‡•™‡•¨ ( K. p. 211), ‘‡§∂‡§∞‡§¶‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡§æ ‡•™, ‡•Ø ( K. p. 85), ’ ‡§∏‡§§‡§§‡§®‡•à‡§∂‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡•´ ‡•® (Ma. P√ª. 76 ), ‘‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ, ‡•Ø, ‡•Æ (K. p. 133 ), ’ ‡§∞‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∞‡•Å ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡•Ø, ‡•ß‡•´ (Ma. P√ª. 74), ‘‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ’ ‡•Ø,‡•¨‡•¶ (Ma. P√ª.73).

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò ‡•¶ ‚Äò‡§™‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ã ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‚Äô ‡•ß, ‡•® ( K. p. 303), ‘‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡•ã‡§™‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡•ß, ‡•™ (Ma. P√ª. p. 57), ‘‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø’ ‡•ß, ‡•™‡•Ø ( K. P. 61), ’ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§≤‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ’ ‡•ß,‡•´‡•ß ( K. p. 289 ), ’ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‘ ‡•ß, ‡•´‡•™ ( K. p. 311 ), ‘‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‘ ‡•®,‡•ß‡•ß ( K. p. 235 ), ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•á‡§§ ‡§ï‡§É ’ ‡•®, ‡•™‡•© ( K. p. 235 ), ‘‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‘ ‡•®, ‡•™‡•´ ( K. p. 311 ), ’ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä ‘ ‡•©,‡•ß‡•¨ (K. p. 184 ), ‘‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç ‘ ‡•©, ‡•®‡•Ø ( K. p. 117 ), ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∂‡§µ‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó‡§É ‘ ‡•ß‡•¶, ‡•ß‡•Ø ( M. Pu. p. 65 ), ‘‡§¨‡§π‡•Å ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‘ ‡•ß‡•ß, ‡•©‡•Ø ( K. P. 285 ), ’ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•ß‡•Æ, ‡•©‡•® ( K. p. 184 ).

mudi or the Manorama for any of them except for the two passages noted above, nay in some cases (as in ‚Äò‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡•Å‚Äô VI. 11, ‚Äò‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‚Äô I. 10) actually solves the difficulty either in the way adopted by the V·πõittik√¢ra or in some way other than the one followed by Bha·π≠·π≠oji D√Ækshita, it is quite clear that Mallin√•tha lived before Bha·π≠·π≠oji D√Ækshita.

Thus with regard to the third question as to whether the two references to the Siddhanta-Kaumudi are the author’s own references or whether they are later interpolations, the answer is quite clear that they must be considered as interpolations. They may have been originally marginal notes of some copyist and afterwards inserted into the com- mentary. It is also to be remembered that it is only from two manuscripts that the text of the commentary is settled. I tried my best to see whether these references are correct by comparing them with the text of the commentary as found in other manuscripts; but I failed, as copies of the commentary of Mallin√¢tha are found only in the Southern parts and there too they are rare. With regard to these references, however, my conclusion is found to be correct. I have been able to secure a copy of the commentary of Mallin√¢tha on C. VIII. St. 16 from another manuscript in charge of the Theosophical Society of Madras and I found that it was in every respect the same as what is printed in this work with this exception that the reference to the Kaumudi (‚Äò‡§ï‡•å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äô), was omitted there. It must also be noted that the same S√ªtra " **‚Äú‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‚Äî‚Äù**is mentioned by Mallin√¢tha in preceding verses (C. V. St. 19, C. V. St. 37) as found in the K√¢≈õik√¢ and not in the Kaumudi and there no remark is made as in C. VIII. St. 10 as to the difference of the readings as found in the V·πõitti and the Kaumudt. It is thus very probable, almost certain, that this reference to the Kaumudi is spurious. As regards the second reference to the Kaumudi (C. I. St. 23) I have secured, through the untiring efforts of my friend, Prof. R√¢dh√¢krish·πáa, a copy of the commentary of Mallin√¢tha from another manuscript at Udamal pet, in which the reference to the Kaumud√Æ is omitted. I therefore.

conclude that the commentator on Bhatti is the same Mallin√¢tha that has commented upon the Raghuvams’a, the Kum√¢rasambhava, the Meghad√ªta, the Kir√¢t√¢rjun√Æya, and the S’is’up√¢lavadha, that he flourished before Bha·π≠·π≠oji D√Ækshita and that the two references to the Siddh√¢ntakaumud√Æ in the commentary are interpolations.

K. P. TRIVEDI

.

Ahmed√¢b√¢d, 11th Oct. 1897.

‡§Ö‡§≠‡§øo or ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø.
‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•¶ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤.

‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•¶ ‡§ó‡•Å‡•¶ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ.
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•¶and ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•¶ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§.
‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°.
‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•¶ ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞.
‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ.
‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø.
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ.
‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ.
‡§ú‡§Ø‡•¶ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ.
‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡•¶ ‡§®‡•É‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£.
‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•¶ ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞.
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞.
‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°.
‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§â‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß (Benares edition )
‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§™‡•Ç‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß (Benares edition).
‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø.
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ.
‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ü.
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏.
‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä.
‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•¶ .‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø.
‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡•¶ ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂.
‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò ‡•¶ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡§µ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü.
‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£,
.‡§µ‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï.
‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§•.
‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡•¶ ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∂‡•á‡§ñ‡§∞.
‡§∏‡•¶ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó.
‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§ï‡•å ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä.
‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡•¶ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡•¶ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø.
‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡•¶ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø.
‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡•¶ ‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞.

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ

‡§Ü‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡••

‡§Ü‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•á ‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§É‡••‡•®‡••

‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡•§
‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§∂‡•ç‡§õ‡§ü‡§æ‡§É‡••‡•©‡••

‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ó‡§£‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡•à‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä-
‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡§ó‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§´‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§Ω‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§É‡••‡•™‡••

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§•‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§∏‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§•‡•Ä‡§®‡§ß‡•Ä‡§É‡••‡•´‡••

‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§•‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§•‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡••‡•¨‡••

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã ‡§Æ

‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ã ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§É‡••‡•≠‡••

‡§®‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§∂‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡•§
‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§µ‡§ß‡§É ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É‡••‡•Æ‡••

‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••‡•Ø‡••

‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§™‡§∞‡§≠‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§§‡§¶‡§ø‡§π ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ
‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡•¶‡••

‡§á‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§
‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••‡•ß‡•ß‡••

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

‡••‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É‡••

‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡••‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

<MISSING_FIG href="../books_images/U-IMG-1725979842dari.PNG"/>

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§É
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§É‡•§
‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§Ø‡§Ç
‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••‡•ß‡••

‡§Ö‡§• ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‘‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•á‡§Ω‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡•§ ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ú‡•á’‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§É‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‘‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§ò‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ß‡•å‡§∞‡•á‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡•ß. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‘‡§µ‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡•å’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É‡•• ‡§á‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡§ß‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§É ‡§ï‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•• ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ñ‡§æ

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ß‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§π‡§ö‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§É ‡§∏‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ö‡•ç" ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ü‡§ö‡•ç‡•• ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡•• ‚Äú‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ñ‡§ö‡•ç‡••‚Äú‡§ñ‡§ö‡§ø-‡§ú‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‚Äî‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É‡•• ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§• ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡•É‡•É‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§™‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ï‡§É‚Äù‡•• ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‚Äî‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§™‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ô‡§ø‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ß‡§É‡•• ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡§∂‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§ü‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡•• ‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É‡•• ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ô‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∞‡§ú‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•• ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‚Äî‚Äò‡§§‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ‡§™‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•• ‚Äò‡§Ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•• ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡•• ‚Äò‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡§ø‡§π ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ú‡§≠‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§ú‡§ó‡§æ‡§É‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•• ‡§è‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§µ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§™‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§≠‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‚Äò‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ú‡•å‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•å ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§™‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡•• ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ó‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§§‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á‚Äî‚Äò‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§£‡§æ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•å ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§≠‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ú‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§≠‡•à‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§∞‡•ã‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§É‚Äô‡•• ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü
‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡•É‡§®‡§™‡§æ46‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•å
‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§¶‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡••‡•®‡••

‡•®.‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•• ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡•• ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡§∂‡§∞‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§É‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•• ‚Äò‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Ä‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É‡•• ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§ô‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§ô‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡§≤‡•É‡§ô‡•ã‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ô‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§É‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø ‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡•• ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§°‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äù‡•§‚Äú‡§Ü‡§ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö" ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•• ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§É ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§°‡§ö‡•ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§Ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• “‡§ù‡§≤‡•ã ‡§ù‡§≤‡§ø” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§É‡•• ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡•É‡§®‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•à‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•• “‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§Æ‡•É‡§∂‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§§‡•É‡§™‡§¶‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É”‡•• “‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§™‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á” ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É‡•• “‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‚Äî” ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•• ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‘‡§è‡§∑ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•É‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§É‡•• ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‚Äò‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‚Äò‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®‡§™‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§¢‡§É ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§ü‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç‡•§ ‘‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‚Äù ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî" ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§∑‡§°‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§ô‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•á

‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‚Äú‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•á‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•å ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•å‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ö‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§É‡•§ ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∂‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§û‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•• ‡§â‡§™‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§π‡•ã ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‚Äî‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§π‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ω‡§ö‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§≤‡•ã‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§ï‡§∑‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É"‡•• ‚Äú‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‡§ö‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§É‡•• ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‚Äù ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§ò‡•ã‡§É" ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ö ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•• ‚Äú‡§á‡§ü ‡§à‡§ü‡§ø‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§É‡•• ‡§á‡§π ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ω‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•å‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§≠‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ω‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§É‡•§ ‚Äò‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•å‡§ó‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ø‡§É’ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡••

‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ò‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ47‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç
‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ω‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§
‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•å
‡§Ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•Å‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§§‡•ç‡••‡•©‡••

‡•©. ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§ ‚Äò‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§∏‡•Å‚Äô ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡•å‡•§ ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ò‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‚Äî" ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§É‡•• ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø ‚Äú‡§á‡§ü ‡§à‡§ü‡§ø‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§™‡§É‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò‡•å‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§®‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§É‡•• ‚Äú‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§É‚Äù ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•• ‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡§ø‡§ü‡•ã ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ô‡•ç‡•• ‚Äú‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø-
